# RENAL ADENOMA 

$\diamond$ Small adenoma $<3 \mathrm{~cm}$ should be considered a renal cell carcinoma of low metastatic potential = borderline renal cell carcinoma!
Frequency: in 7-15-23\% of adults (autopsies); most common cortical lesion; increasing with age (in $10 \%$ of patients $<40$ years of age, in $40 \%$ of patients $>70$ years of age); increased frequency in tobacco users + patients on long-term dialysis
Age: usually $>30$ years; $\mathrm{M}+\mathrm{F}=3 \div 1$
Types:
(1) Papillary adenoma / cystadenoma (38\%)
(2) Tubular adenoma (38\%)
(3) Mixed type adenoma ( $21 \%$ )
(4) Alveolar adenoma ( $3 \%$ ) = precursor of RCC
$\checkmark$ solitary in $75 \%$, multiple in $25 \%$
$\checkmark$ usually $<3 \mathrm{~cm}$ in size; subcapsular cortical location
$\checkmark$ impossible to differentiate from renal cell carcinoma
Cx: premalignant (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
Prognosis: average growth rate of 0.4 (range, $0.2-3.5$ ) cm annually; tumors growing $<0.25 \mathrm{~cm}$ annually rarely metastasize; tumors growing $>0.6 \mathrm{~cm}$ annually frequently metastasize

## RENAL AGENESIS

## Mechanism:

(a) formation failure
$=$ failure of ureteral bud to form

- hemitrigone $=$ absence of ipsilateral trigone + ureteral orifice
(b) induction failure
$=$ failure of growing ureteral bud to induce metanephric tissue
- blind-ending ureter


## Unilateral Renal Agenesis

Prevalence: $1 \div 600$ to $1 \div 1,000$ pregnancies; $\mathrm{M}+\mathrm{F}=1.8 \div 1$
Risk of recurrence: $4.5 \%$
Often coexisting with other anomalies:

1. Genital abnormalities:
(a) in male ( $10-15 \%$ ): Zinner syndrome
$=$ rare congenital abnormality of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct = TRIAD of (1) hypoplasia or agenesis of testis / vas deferens, (2) seminal vesicle cyst, (3) ipsilateral ejaculatory duct obstruction
[Alfred Zinner (?1887-1967), urologist in Wien, Austria]
(b) in female ( $25-50 \%$ ): unicornuate / bicornuate / hypoplastic / absent uterus, absent / aplastic vagina
$\diamond 90 \%$ of women with renal agenesis have uterine anomalies
$\diamond 30-40 \%$ of women with uterine anomalies have renal agenesis
2. Turner syndrome, trisomy, Fanconi anemia, Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome

Location: $\mathrm{L}>\mathrm{R}$
$\checkmark$ visualization of single kidney (DDx: additional kidney in ectopic location)
$\checkmark$ absent adrenal gland $(11 \%)$
$\checkmark$ absent / rudimentary renal vessels
$\checkmark$ colon occupies renal fossa
$\checkmark$ compensatory contralateral renal hypertrophy ( $50 \%$ )

# Bilateral Renal Agenesis 

$=$ POTTER SYNDROME
Prevalence: $1 \div 3,000$ to $1 \div 10,000$ pregnancies; $\mathrm{M} \div \mathrm{F}=2.5 \div 1$
Risk of recurrence: $<1 \%$

- Potter's facies = low-set ears, redundant skin, parrot-beaked nose, receding chin
$\diamond$ US sensitivity is ONLY $69-73 \% \leftarrow$ decreased visualization from oligohydramnios + discoid-shaped adrenal glands simulating kidneys!
$\checkmark$ severe oligohydramnios (after 14 weeks MA)
$\checkmark$ bilateral absence of kidneys, ureters, renal arteries (after 12 weeks)
$\checkmark$ inability to visualize renal arteries by color duplex
$\checkmark$ inability to visualize urine in fetal bladder (after 13 weeks) $\leftarrow$ bladder agenesis / hypoplasia; negative furosemide test (20-60 mg IV) NOT diagnostic (fetuses with severe IUGR may not be capable of diuresis)
$\checkmark$ flattened discoid shape of adrenals $\leftarrow$ absence of pressure by kidney
$\checkmark$ bell-shaped thorax in mid to late $3^{\text {rd }}$ trimester $\leftarrow$ pulmonary hypoplasia
$\checkmark$ compression deformities of extremities $\rightarrow$ clubfoot, flexion contractures, joint dislocations (eg, hip)
Prognosis: stillbirths (24-38\%); invariably fatal in the first days of life $\leftarrow$ pulmonary hypoplasia
$D D x$ : functional cause of in utero renal failure (eg, severe IUGR)


## Potter Sequence

$=$ hypoplasia of lungs, bowing of legs, broad hands, loose skin, growth retardation associated with long-standing severe oligohydramnios
Cause: renal agenesis, urethral obstruction, prolonged rupture of membranes, severe IUGR

## RENAL ARTERY ANEURYSM

Incidence: $0.01-0.10 \% ; 22 \%$ of visceral aneurysms
Cause: medial fibrodysplasia, penetrating trauma
Age: $50-61$ years; $\mathrm{M} \div \mathrm{F}=1 \div 1$
Location: $\mathrm{R}>\mathrm{L} ; 1^{\text {st }}$-order branch of main renal artery (usually)
Type:
(a) saccular ( $80 \%$ ): near first bifurcation of main renal artery; variety of causes (congenital; associated with medial fibroplasia + atherosclerosis)
(b) fusiform ( $20 \%$ ): $\leftarrow$ advanced renal artery medial fibrodysplasia; not calcified
(c) dissecting: traumatic, spontaneous (atherosclerosis, intimal fibroplasia, perimedial fibroplasia), iatrogenic

- usually asymptomatic (in $>50 \%$ )

Rx: Endovascular therapy ( $>80 \%$ success rate)
Cx: (1) Hypertension (unusual)
(2) Perinephric / retroperitoneal hemorrhage (rare) with increased risk in peripartum women
(3) Formation of AV fistula
(4) Peripheral renal embolization $\leftarrow$ mural thrombus
(5) Thrombosis
(6) Hematuria

# Extrarenal Aneurysm ( $9 / 4$ )

1. Atherosclerotic (most common)
2. Fibromuscular dysplasia
3. Pregnancy
4. Mesenchymal disease: neurofibromatosis, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
B. FALSE ANEURYSM
5. Trauma; renal artery angioplasty
6. Behçet disease

Organism: Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, Pneumococcus, Salmonella

(2) Surgery for (a) interval growth, (b) emboli to kidney, (c) in woman of childbearing age, (d) diminished renal function / ischemia / hypertension / dissection

# RENAL ARTERY STENOSIS 

Prevalence: $1-2-4 \%$ of hypertensive individuals; $4.3 \%$ of autopsies; $10 \%$ of hypertensive individuals with coronary artery disease; $25 \%$ of patients with hypertension that is difficult to control; in $45 \%$ of patients with malignant hypertension; in $45 \%$ of patients with peripheral vascular disease

## Cause:

1. Atherosclerosis ( $60-90 \%$ ): mostly in proximal 2 cm of main renal artery
$\diamond$ Any of multiple renal arteries (occurring in $14-28 \%$ of the population) may be affected!
2. Fibromuscular dysplasia $(10-30 \%)$
3. Others $(<10 \%)$ : thromboembolic disease, arterial dissection, infrarenal aortic aneurysm, arteriovenous fistula, vasculitis (Buerger disease, Takayasu disease, polyarteritis nodosa, postradiation), neurofibromatosis, retroperitoneal fibrosis
Pathophysiology:
$\downarrow$ perfusion pressure of glomeruli $\rightarrow$ stimulates production of renin in juxtaglomerular apparatus + angiotensin II in kidney; renin converts circulating angiotensinogen ( $\alpha 2$-globulin) into angiotensin $\mathrm{I} \rightarrow$ subsequently converted by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE present in vascular endothelium) $\rightarrow$ into angiotensin II releasing aldosterone; aldosterone increases salt + water retention; angiotensin II + aldosterone vasoconstrict vessels (especially intraglomerular efferent arteriole to maintain filtration pressure)
$\diamond$ ACE inhibition may impair overall renal function $\leftarrow$ disruption of autoregulatory

mechanism of GFR (with renal artery stenosis in both kidneys / solitary kidney)
Renin production stimuli:
(a) baroreceptors in afferent glomerular arteriole sense $\Downarrow$ stretching of arteriolar wall with diminished blood flow
(b) chemoreceptors of macula densa located in first part of the distal tubule sense a $\Downarrow$ amount of sodium and chloride (which have been largely reabsorbed $\leftarrow$ low GFR)
Histo: tubular atrophy and shrinkage of glomeruli

- abdominal / flank pain, hematuria, oliguria, anuria
- renin-mediated hypertension $\leftarrow$ ischemia
- low urine sodium concentration

Hemodynamic significance determined by:
(a) elevated renin levels in ipsilateral renal vein $\geq 1.5 \div 1$
(b) presence of collateral vessels
(c) greater than $70 \%$ stenosis with poststenotic dilatation
(d) transstenotic pressure gradient $\geq 40 \mathrm{mmHg}$
(e) decrease in renal size
$\diamond 15-20 \%$ of patients remain hypertensive after restoration of normal renal blood flow ( $=$ renal artery stenosis without renovascular hypertension)!
Patient selection criteria for screening test:
$=$ clinical signs associated with moderate-to-high risk of renovascular hypertension (HTN):

1. Abrupt onset or severe HTN
2. HTN resistant to 3-drug therapy in compliant patient
3. Abdominal / flank bruits
4. Unexplained azotemia in elderly patient with HTN
5. Worsening renal function during antihypertensive therapy, especially with ACEIs
6. Grade $3 / 4$ hypertensive retinopathy
7. Occlusive disease in other vascular beds
8. Onset of $\mathrm{HTN}<30$ years or $>55$ years of age
9. Recurrent pulmonary edema in elderly patient with HTN
10. HTN in infants with an umbilical artery catheter
11. HTN in children
$\sqrt{ }$ normal / decreased renal size ( $\mathrm{R} 2 \mathrm{~cm}<\mathrm{L} ; \mathrm{L} 1.5 \mathrm{~cm}<\mathrm{R}$ ) with smooth contour
$\checkmark$ vascular calcifications (aneurysm / atherosclerosis)
IVP ( $60 \%$ true-positive rate, $22 \%$ false-negative rate):
$\checkmark$ delayed appearance of contrast material $\leftarrow$ decreased glomerular filtration
$\checkmark$ increased density of contrast material $\leftarrow$ increased water reabsorption
$\checkmark$ delayed washout of contrast material $\leftarrow$ prolonged urine transit time
$\checkmark$ lack of distension of collecting system
$\checkmark$ global attenuation of contrast density; urogram may be normal with adequate collateral circulation
$\checkmark$ notching of proximal ureter $\leftarrow$ enlargement of collateral vessels
CT:
$\checkmark$ prolongation of cortical nephrographic phase + persistent corticomedullary differentiation
$\checkmark$ CT angiography ( $2-3-\mathrm{mm}$ collimation, pitch $\leq 1.5-2.0$ ): specificity of real-time interactive volume rendering $>$ maximum-intensity projection $>$ shaded-surface display

MRA ( $>95 \%$ sensitive, $>90 \%$ specific):
$\sqrt{ }$ tendency to overestimate stenosis
Limitations:
> evaluation of branch vessels
> presence of metallic stent
> detection of accessory arteries
> evaluation of small renal arteries

Angiography:
(a) conventional angiography $=$ "gold standard" test

(b) intravenous digital subtraction angiography: does not address hemodynamic significance
ACE inhibitor scintigraphy ( $51-96 \%$ sensitive, $80-93 \%$ specific):
= screening test for renovascular hypertension (not renal artery stenosis) with angiotensinconverting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) challenge
$\diamond$ ACE inhibition may impair overall renal function due to disruption of autoregulatory mechanism of GFR (with renal artery stenosis in both kidneys / solitary kidney)
Pharmacology:
affected kidney responds to decreased arteriolar flow by releasing renin + angiotensin II (= extremely potent vasoconstrictor acting on the efferent renal arteriole to increase filtration pressure) in juxtaglomerular apparatus; ACE inhibitors (eg, captopril, enalapril) $\rightarrow$ block ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) $\rightarrow$ reduces GFR (51-96\% sensitive, 80-93\% specific)
$\checkmark$ unilateral parenchymal retention after ACEI: reduced GFR $\rightarrow \Downarrow$ urinary output $+\uparrow$ radiotracer retention
$=>90 \%$ probability of renovascular hypertension
$\checkmark$ change in grade of differential renal function from baseline grade $0 / 1$ by $>1$ grade
$=$ high probability for renal artery stenosis
$\checkmark$ abnormal baseline curve without change
$=$ indeterminate for renovascular hypertension
$\checkmark$ functional improvement following ACEI challenge
$=$ low probability for renovascular hypertension
Semiquantitative interpretation of time-activity renograms:
$\checkmark$ normal ACE inhibitor scintigram ( $<10 \%$ probability for renovascular hypertension)
$\checkmark$ criteria for high probability ( $>90 \%$ ):
$\checkmark$ worsening of scintigraphic curve
$\checkmark$ reduction in relative uptake with $>10 \%$ change after ACE inhibition
$\checkmark$ prolongation of parenchymal transit time with $>2 \mathrm{~min}$ delay of excretion into renal pelvis
$\checkmark \uparrow$ in 20 -minute peak uptake ratio $>0.15$ from baseline
$\checkmark$ prolongation of $\mathrm{T}_{\text {max }}$ of $>2 \mathrm{~min} / 40 \%$
$\checkmark$ asymmetry of renal uptake $<40 \%$ of total renal uptake
$\checkmark$ bilateral symmetrical changes are usually due to:
(a) hypotension
(b) salt depletion
(c) use of calcium channel blockers
(d) low urine flow rate

Decreased accuracy with:
(1) Bilateral renal artery stenosis
(2) Impaired renal function
(3) Urinary obstruction
(4) Chronic ACE inhibitor therapy

Sources of error:
(1) Failure to administer ACEIs properly:

(a) ingestion of food within 4 hours of taking captopril
(b) paravenous infiltration
(2) Causes of abnormal whole-kidney renograms:
(a) renal pelvic retention
(b) dehydration
(c) hypotension
(d) full bladder impairing drainage

Duplex US:
(1) direct signs $=$ visualization of renal artery stenosis
$\sqrt{ }$ peak systolic velocity $>150 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{sec}$ for angles $<60^{\circ}$ or $180 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{sec}$ for angles $>70^{\circ}$ (with many false positives due to suboptimal Doppler angles)
$\sqrt{ }$ ratio of peak renal artery velocity to peak aortic center stream velocity $>3.5$ (for $>$ $60 \%$ stenosis; $0-91 \%$ sensitive, $37-97 \%$ specific)
$\sqrt{ }$ poststenotic spectral broadening $\pm$ flow reversal
$\sqrt{ }$ absence of blood flow during diastole (for $>50 \%$ stenosis)
$\sqrt{ }$ NO detectable Doppler signal with good visualization of renal artery (= arterial occlusion)
Problems:

(b) multiple renal arteries in $16-28 \%$
(c) "false" tracings from large collateral vessels / reconstituted segments of main renal artery
(d) need to visualize entire length of renal artery
(e) transmitted cardiac / aortic pulsations obscure renal artery waveform recordings
(2) indirect signs $=$ analysis of intrarenal arterial Doppler waveforms

$\sqrt{ }$ segmental arterial flow detectable with renal artery occlusion $\leftarrow$ collateral circulation

# Arteriosclerotic Renal Artery Disease 

Frequency: in up to $6 \%$ of hypertensive patients; most common cause of secondary hypertension
Age: $\quad>50$ years; $\mathrm{M}>\mathrm{F}$
Path: lesion primarily involving intima

- worsening of preexistent hypertension
- abrupt onset of severe hypertension $>180 / 110 \mathrm{mmHg}$
- vascular bruit in $40-50 \%$ (present in $20 \%$ of hypertensive patients without renal artery stenosis)
Associated with: severe arteriosclerosis of aorta, cerebral, coronary, peripheral arteries
Location: main renal artery ( $93 \%$ ) + additional stenosis of renal artery branch ( $7 \%$ ); bilateral in $31 \%$
$\sqrt{ }$ eccentric stenosis in proximal 2 cm of renal artery, frequently involving orifice
$\sqrt{ }$ decrease in renal length over time ( $=$ high-grade renal artery stenosis with risk for occlusion)
Prognosis: progression of atherosclerotic lesion (40-45\%) to renal atrophy, arterial occlusion, ischemic renal failure
Cx: azotemia with
(a) bilateral renal artery stenoses
(b) unilateral renal artery stenosis + poorly functioning contralateral kidney
$\diamond$ Reversible azotemia may be induced by treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors / sodium nitroprusside!
Rx: (1) Three-step antihypertensive therapy (control of hypertension difficult)
(2) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (eg, captopril PO, enalaprilat IV)
(3) Renal artery angioplasty ( $80 \%$ success for nonostial lesion, $25-30 \%$ for ostial lesion)
(4) Surgical revascularization ( $80-90 \%$ success for any lesion location)
> hypertension improved in $66 \%$
> improvement / stabilization of renal function in $27-80 \%$


## Fibromuscular Dysplasia of Renal Artery

Prevalence: $4 \div 1000$ symptomatic patients of renal artery $+2 \div 1000$ of extracranial carotid artery involvement (2007); $35 \%$ of renal artery stenoses; $25 \%$ of all cases of renovascular hypertension
Age: most common cause of renovascular hypertension in children + young adults $<30-40$ years; $\mathrm{M} \div \mathrm{F}=1 \div 3$
Associated with: fibromuscular dysplasia of other aortic branches in 1-2\%: celiac artery, hepatic artery, splenic artery, mesenteric artery, iliac artery, internal carotid artery

- hypertension, progressive renal insufficiency

Sites: mid and distal main renal artery ( $79 \%$ ), renal artery branches ( $4 \%$ ), combination $(17 \%)$; proximal $1 / 3$ of main renal artery spared in $98 \%$; bilateral in ${ }^{2} / ; \mathrm{R} \div \mathrm{L}=4 \div 1$
Types:

1. Intimal fibroplasia $=$ intimal hyperplasia
$\sqrt{ }$ narrow annular radiolucent band in main renal artery + major segmental branches; often bilateral
$\sqrt{ }$ poststenotic fusiform dilatation
2. Medial fibroplasia with microaneurysm
$\sqrt{ }$ "string-of-beads / string-of-pearls sign" = alternating areas of stenoses + aneurysms in mid + distal renal artery + branches; usually bilateral
3. Fibromuscular hyperplasia
$\sqrt{ }$ long smooth tubular narrowing of main renal artery and branches
4. Perimedial fibroplasia
$\sqrt{ }$ beading without aneurysm formation of distal (mostly right) main renal artery
5. Medial dissection
$\sqrt{ }$ false channel in main renal artery + branches
6. Adventitial fibroplasia
$\sqrt{ }$ long segmental stenosis of main renal artery + large branches
Prognosis: progression of lesion in $20 \% \rightarrow$ decline in renal function
Cx: (1) Giant aneurysm
(2) AV fistula between renal artery + vein (in medial fibroplasia)
Rx: (1) Resection of diseased segment with end-to-end anastomosis
(2) Replacement by autogenous vein graft, excision + repair by patch angioplasty
(3) Transluminal balloon angioplasty ( $90 \%$ success rate with very low restenosis rate)

# Neurofibromatosis of Renal Artery 

Hypertension in neurofibromatosis due to:
(1) Pheochromocytoma
(2) Renal artery stenosis
$\diamond$ Renal artery involvement mainly seen in children!

## Types:

(a) mesodermal dysplasia of arterial wall with fibrous transformation (common)
(b) narrowing of main renal artery by periarterial neurofibroma (rare)
$\sqrt{ }$ saccular funnel-shaped aneurysm involving aorta / main renal artery
$\sqrt{ }$ smooth / nodular stenosis (mural / adventitial neurofibroma) in proximal renal artery
$\sqrt{ }$ intrarenal aneurysm (rare)
$D D x$ : fibromuscular dysplasia; congenital renal artery stenosis

## RENAL CELL CARCINOMA

$=\mathrm{RCC}=$ RENAL ADENOCARCINOMA $=$ HYPERNEPHROMA
Prevalence: $2-3 \%$ of all adult visceral cancers (frequency approximates ovarian cancer, gastric cancer, pancreatic cancer, leukemia); 65,000 new RCCs in USA annually with 13,500 deaths (2012); 85-90\% of all renal malignant primaries in adults; $7^{\text {th }} / 12^{\text {th }}$

most common malignancy in men / women; $61 \%$ found incidentally with imaging Age: $6^{\text {th }}-7^{\text {th }}$ decade (generally $>40$ years); median age of 55 years; $2 \%$ occur in children in first 2 decades of life; frequency increasing with age; $\mathrm{M} \div \mathrm{F}=1.6 \div 1$ Path: arises from proximal tubular cells Tumor growth pattern: papillary ( $5-15 \%$, best prognosis); trabecular / tubular / cystic / solid (poorer prognosis) Associated with familial and hereditary syndromes: (1) von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (2) Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome: rare autosomal dominant disease characterized by hair follicle hamartomas, renal tumors, pulmonary cysts (3) Hereditary papillary renal cancer # Predisposed: (1) Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome ( $10-25 \%$ ): multiple often small intracystic tumors (hemangioblastoma, retinal angioma, renal cysts) manifesting at a young age (2) Hemodialysis (in $1.4-2.6 \%$ ) (3) Acquired cystic disease of uremia (3.3-6.1\%; 7 x increased risk) (4) Tobacco; phenacetin abuse (5) Obesity Histopathologic subtypes associated with different prognosis: (a) clear cell RCC ( $65-80 \%$ ) (b) multilocular clear cell RCC $(<1 \%)$ (c) papillary $\operatorname{RCC}(15-20 \%)=\mathrm{pRCC}$ (d) chromophobe RCC (4-11\%) (e) collecting duct carcinoma of Bellini $(<1 \%)$ (f) renal medullary carcinoma (g) unclassified > Xp11 translocation carcinoma > carcinoma associated with neuroblastoma > mucinous tubular spindle cell carcinoma Grading (Fuhrman): Grade 1 tumor cells with $10-\mu \mathrm{m}$ small round uniform nuclei without nucleoli Grade 2 tumor cells with $15-\mu \mathrm{m}$ nuclei, subtle irregular outline and with nucleoli Grade 3 tumor cells with $20-\mu \mathrm{m}$ nuclei obvious irregular outline and prominent larger nucleoli Grade 4 tumor cells with bizarre multilobed nuclei and heavy clumps of chromatin Staging: | Staging of Renal Cell Carcinoma
American Joint Committee on Cancer (2002) | | :-- | | T1 tumor $\leq 7 \mathrm{~cm}$ confined to kidney | | T2 tumor $>7 \mathrm{~cm}$ confined to kidney | | T3 invasion of perinephric fat / adrenal gland / major vein | | T4 extension beyond Gerota fascia / distant metastasis | Staging accuracy: $84-91 \%$ for CT; $82-96 \%$ for MR; poor for US

Regional extension: into lymph nodes ( $9-23 \%$ ); into main renal vein ( $21-35 \%$ ); into IVC $(4-10 \%)$
Multiple RCC: commonly in Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome; hereditary RCC; sporadic in 4$15 \%$; bilateral in $1-3 \%$

- hematuria (56\%), flank pain (36\%), weight loss (27\%), fever (11-15\%); normochromic normocytic anemia ( $28-40 \%$ )

- Stauffer syndrome ( $15 \%$ ) = nephrogenic hepatopathy = hepatosplenomegaly + abnormal liver function in absence of hepatic metastases (? tumor hepatotoxin)
- Paraneoplastic syndromes: erythrocytosis (2\%); hypercalcemia $\leftarrow$ parathormone, prostaglandin, vitamin D metabolites)
$\checkmark$ well-marginated often lobulated solitary mass:

$\checkmark$ cysts:

$\checkmark$ Tumor stage + histologic grade are the most important prognosticators!
> 5-year survival rates for stages I, II, III, IV are $85-100 \%, 45-65 \%, 20-40 \%, 0-10 \%$;
> 10-year survival rates for stages I, II, III, IV are $56 \%, 28 \%, 20 \%, 3 \%$
$>4.4 \% 3$-year survival rate if untreated
> papillary carcinomas have a better prognosis than nonpapillary carcinomas!
> clear cell + granular cell cancers have a better prognosis than spindle cell + anaplastic

cancers
Recurrence: in $11 \%$ after 10 years
$R x$ :
(1) Radical nephrectomy ( $2-5 \%$ operative mortality)
N.B.: chemo- / radiation- / immunotherapy cannot cure metastatic renal cell carcinoma!
(2) Nephron-sparing surgery (partial nephrectomy) with solitary functioning kidney, compromised renal function, multiple bilateral tumors, small RCC ( $<3 \mathrm{~cm}$ in diameter, polar, cortical, far from renal hilum / sinus / collecting system)
(3) $<5 \%$ of metastatic RCCs respond to chemotherapy; only $20 \%$ respond to interleukin-2 / interferon- $\alpha$

# Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (cRCC) 

$=$ CONVENTIONAL $\mathrm{RCC}=\mathrm{cRCC}$
Prevalence: $60-80 \%$ of all RCCs
Associated with: von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
Origin: derived from epithelium of proximal convoluted tubule $\rightarrow$ cortical location and expansile growth
Path: central necrosis (common); may be predominantly cystic with only minor solid enhancing component
Histo: rich in cytoplasmic glycogen + lipid content that washes away (hence "clear") during tissue processing; extensive thin-walled sinusoid-like vessels
Genetics: translocation of short arm of chromosome 3; mutation of von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene $\rightarrow$ synthesizes protein that suppresses hypoxia-induced genes involved in angiogenesis
Location: in cortex as exophytic hypervascular solid mass
$\checkmark$ heterogeneous appearance $\leftarrow$ macroscopic areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, cystic changes, calcifications
$\checkmark$ greater degree of enhancement than other subtypes $\leftarrow$ CHARACTERISTIC network of small sinusoid blood vessels
MR:
$\checkmark$ tumor isointense to renal parenchyma on T1WI
$\checkmark$ tumor hyperintense to renal parenchyma on T2WI
$\checkmark$ SI loss within solid portions on opposed-phase compared with in-phase images $\leftarrow$ cytoplasmic fat (in $60 \%$ )
$\checkmark \pm$ hypointense rim on both T1- and T2-weighted images = pseudocapsule of compressed adjacent renal parenchyma:
$\checkmark$ interruption of pseudocapsule $\leftarrow$ invasion of perirenal fat in advanced tumor stage
$\checkmark$ imaging of tumor necrosis:
$\checkmark$ homogeneously hypointense area in center of mass on T1WI that is hypo- to hyperintense on T2WI
$\checkmark$ solid rim of tumor peripherally
$\checkmark$ lack of enhancement in necrotic area + marked enhancement of viable tumor component
$\checkmark$ imaging of intratumoral hemorrhage:
$\checkmark$ high signal intensity on both T1- and T2WI = subacute to chronic hemorrhage
$\checkmark$ hypointense on both T1- and T2WI = long-standing hemorrhage predominantly containing hemosiderin
$\checkmark$ hypervascularity during cortical phase $\leftarrow$ network of small sinusoid-like blood vessels
$\checkmark$ renal vein tumor thrombus $=$ higher-stage tumor
Prognosis: 5-year survival rate of $55-60 \%$; poorer than for chromophobe or pRCC

$=$ intrinsic multilocular growth; impossible to distinguish from multilocular cystic nephroma
$\sqrt{ }$ septated variable-sized cysts + septal calcifications
(c) Mural nodule in cystic RCC (20\%)

$\checkmark$ tumor arising in wall of preexisting cyst

$\checkmark$ calcifications
$\checkmark$ atypical contents:

$\checkmark$ signal intensity atypical for water at MRI

# Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma 

$18-28 \%$ of patients have clinically apparent multiple synchronous distant metastases at presentation
$50 \%$ will develop metachronous metastases during follow-up after nephrectomy (in $85 \%$ within 3 years)
Incidence of metastatic disease:
(a) tumors $<3 \mathrm{~cm}: 2.6 \%$
(b) tumors $3-5 \mathrm{~cm}: 15.4 \%$
(c) tumors $>5 \mathrm{~cm}: 78.6 \%$

Number of sites: single+multiple sites $=3 \div 2$
Spread to:
lung ( $45-55 \%$ ) > bone ( $32 \%$ ) > lymph nodes ( $22-34 \%$ ); liver ( $20-33 \%$ ); pancreas(1.6$11 \%$ ); adrenals ( $4.3-19 \%$ ); contralateral kidney ( $11 \%$ ); brain ( $6 \%$ ); heart ( $5 \%$ ); spleen (5\%); bowel (4\%); skin (3\%); ureter (rare)

(a) hematogenous: venous extension ( $20-35 \%$ )
> ascending into IVC $\rightarrow$ right chambers $\rightarrow$ lung $\rightarrow$ systemic circulation
> descending (= venous reflux) into adrenal, gonadal, second lumbar veins $\rightarrow$ (often ipsilateral) ovary / testis / adrenal gland
> with venous thrombosis $\rightarrow$ retroperitoneal and paravertebral Batson plexus
(b) lymphatic:
» regional lymph nodes (N): renal hilar and retroperitoneal (paraaortic + paracaval) nodes
> mediastinal, pelvic, inguinal nodes (M1)
> invasion of thoracic duct $\rightarrow$ thoracic (mediastinal and hilar) / supraclavicular nodes

- cough, bone pain, hemoptysis (as initial symptoms of metastatic disease present in 9\%)

# Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (pRCC) 

Prevalence: $10-15 \%$ (2nd most common) of all RCCs
Age: $\quad 3 \mathrm{rd}-8^{\text {th }}$ decade; $\mathrm{M}+\mathrm{F}=2 \div 1$ to $4 \div 1$
Origin: derived from epithelium of proximal convoluted tubules
Associated with: end-stage renal disease
Path: cystic necrosis + degeneration frequent; familial form associated with trisomy $7 \& 17$
\& loss of Y chromosome in males (similar to papillary adenoma)
Histo: cells surrounding fronds of delicate fibrovascular core; macrophages infiltrating papillary stalks
(a) basophilic $=$ small cuboidal cells with uniform nuclei covering thin papillae
(b) eosinophilic = large eosinophilic cells with pleomorphic nuclei

Growth pattern: papillary, tubular, tubulopapillary
Location: most common of multifocal / bilateral renal tumors!
$\checkmark$ typically hypovascular $\rightarrow$ enhances to a lesser degree compared with clear cell RCC
$\checkmark$ homogeneous slow growing well-encapsulated tumor
$\checkmark$ peripheral calcifications frequent
CECT:
$\checkmark$ little contrast enhancement in all phases to a lesser degree than renal cortex (DDx to hypervascular cRCC)
$\checkmark$ usually homogeneous enhancement if $<3 \mathrm{~cm}$
$\checkmark$ heterogeneous enhancement if $>3 \mathrm{~cm}$ (DDx to usually homogeneously enhancing chromophobe RCC)
MR:
$\checkmark$ fibrous capsule (frequent)
$\checkmark$ hypointense on T1WI + T2WI (DDx to hyperintense cRCC on T2WI)
$\checkmark$ low-grade basophilic (type I) tumor:

$\sqrt{ }$ homogeneously low SI on T2WI
$\checkmark$ hypovascular homogeneous low-level enhancement
$\checkmark$ high-grade eosinophilic (type II) tumor:
$\checkmark$ complex tumor appearance $\leftarrow$ hemorrhage + necrosis
$\checkmark$ enhancing papillary projections at periphery of cystic hemorrhagic mass
US:
$\checkmark$ frequently hypoechoic mass
Prognosis: 5-year survival rate of $80-90 \%$; favorable (smaller mean diameter, lower stage, later metastases than cRCC)
$D D x$ : renal cyst (enhancement of $<10 \mathrm{HU} /$ pseudoenhancement, cyst by US +MR )

Frequency: $7 \%$ of all primary renal tumors during first 2 decades of life;
in childhood: Wilms tumor $+\mathrm{RCC}=30 \div 1$
in $2^{\text {nd }}$ decade: Wilms tumor $+\mathrm{RCC}=1 \div 1$

## RENAL INFARCTION

## Cause:

1. TRAUMA
blunt abdominal trauma with traumatic avulsion / occlusion of renal artery, penetrating vascular injury, surgery
2. EMBOLISM
(a) Cardiac: rheumatic heart disease with arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation), myocardial infarction, prosthetic valve, myocardial trauma, left atrial / mural thrombus, myocardial tumor, subacute bacterial endocarditis $\rightarrow$ septic emboli
(b) Catheters: angiographic catheter manipulation, transcatheter embolization, umbilical artery catheter above level of renal arteries
3. ARTERIAL THROMBOSIS
arteriosclerosis, aneurysm or dissection of aorta / renal artery, thrombangiitis obliterans, polyarteritis nodosa, syphilitic cardiovascular disease, sickle cell disease, paraneoplastic syndrome (Trousseau syndrome), hypercoagulable state
4. VASCULITIS
polyarteritis nodosa, SLE, drug-induced vasculitis
5. Sudden complete renal vein thrombosis

- sudden onset of flank / back pain
- $\pm$ hematuria, proteinuria, fever, leukocytosis

A. PRERENAL

1. Renal artery stenosis $(1-4 \%)$

(b) long-segment stenosis of proximal artery (close to anastomosis) > distal artery

- nonspecific audible bruit over graft (occasionally)

# Aseptic Necrosis with Renal Transplant 

Most common long-term disabling complication; femoral head most common site; bilateral in $59-80 \%$
Frequency: 6-15-29\% within 3 years after surgery
Mean time of onset: 9-19 (range, 5-126) months after transplantation when symptoms develop
Risk factors:
dose + method of glucocorticoid administration, duration + quality of dialysis before transplantation, secondary hyperparathyroidism, allograft dysfunction, liver disease, previous transplantation, iron overload, increased protein catabolism during dialysis
Pathophysiology of corticosteroid therapy:
(1) Fat embolism $\rightarrow$ fat globules occlude subchondral end arteries
(2) Increase in fat cell volume in closed marrow space $\rightarrow \uparrow$ intramedullary pressure $\rightarrow$ diminished perfusion
(3) Osteopenia $\rightarrow$ increased bone fragility
(4) Reduced sensibility to pain $\rightarrow$ loss of protection against excessive stress

Histo: fragmentation, compression, resorption of dead bone, proliferation of granulation tissue, revascularization, production of new bone

- $40 \%$ asymptomatic, joint pain, restriction of movement

Sites: femoral head, femoral condyles (lateral > medial condyle), humeral head
$\sqrt{ }$ subchondral bone resorption
$\sqrt{ }$ patchy osteosclerosis
$\sqrt{ }$ collapse / fragmentation of bone
MR abbreviated T1WI protocol = test of choice!

## RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS

$=$ clinical syndrome characterized by tubular insufficiency to resorb bicarbonate, excrete hydrogen ion, or both (= nonanion gap metabolic acidosis)

- failure to thrive


## Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis

$=$ TYPE 2 RTA
$=$ impaired capacity to absorb HCO3 - in proximal tubule $\rightarrow$ bicarbonate in urine at lower plasma levels than normal
Pathogenesis:
? defect in $\mathrm{Na}+/ \mathrm{HCO} 3$ - cotransport at basolateral membrane; deficit of carbonic anhydrase; parathyroid hormone activates cyclic AMP $\rightarrow$ inhibits carbonic anhydrase $\rightarrow$ hypocalcemia of hyperparathyroidism + various types of Fanconi syndrome

- self-limited acidosis ( $=$ bicarbonate loss stops once bicarbonate threshold of about 15 $\mathrm{mEq} / \mathrm{L}$ is reached)
- unimpaired ability to lower urine $\mathrm{pH}(\mathrm{pH} 4.5-7.8$ depending on level of plasma bicarbonate) by normal excretion of $\mathrm{H}+$

- hypokalemia $\leftarrow$ hyperaldosteronism $\leftarrow$ decreased proximal resorption of NaCl
$\sqrt{ }$ rickets / osteomalacia
N.B.: NEVER nephrocalcinosis / nephrolithiasis $\leftarrow$ normal urinary citrate excretion, low urine pH , self-limited less severe acidosis with less calcium release from bone
$D x$ : bicarbonate titration test, large requirement of alkali to sustain plasma bicarbonate level at $22 \mathrm{mmol} / \mathrm{L}$
$R x$ : administration of alkali $\pm$ potassium $\pm$ hydrochloro-thiazide


# Infantile Type of Primary Proximal RTA 

Age: diagnosed within first 18 months of life; usually male patient

- excessive vomiting in early infancy
- growth retardation ( $<3^{\text {rd }}$ percentile)
- metabolic hyperchloremic acidosis
- normal quantities of net acid excretion

Prognosis: transient type with spontaneous remission

## Secondary Proximal RTA

$=$ tubular defect of bicarbonate resorption associated with other tubular dysfunction/ generalized disease
Cause:
) Fanconi syndrome, cystinosis, Lowe syndrome, hereditary fructose intolerance, glycogen storage disease, galactosemia, tyrosinemia, Wilson disease, Leigh syndrome
$) 1^{\circ}+2^{\circ}$ hyperparathyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, mineralocorticoid deficiency, osteopetrosis
> medullary cystic disease, renal transplantation, vascular accident to kidney in newborn period, multiple myeloma, amyloidosis, nephrotic syndrome, cyanotic CHD, Sjögren syndrome
> intoxication with cadmium, outdated tetracycline, methylchromone, 6-mercaptopurine

## Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis

$=$ TYPE 1 RTA (first type discovered)
$=$ impaired ability to secrete $\mathrm{H}+$ in distal tubule despite low levels of plasma bicarbonate (urine cannot be acidified with pH invariably high at $>5.5-6.0$ )
Pathophysiology:
primary defect of nonacidification of urine followed by
(a) hyperchloremia:
small constant loss of serum sodium bicarbonate ( NaHCO 3 ) without concomitant loss of chloride ( $=\mathrm{NaCl}$ retention) $\rightarrow$ shrinkage of ECF volume
(b) chronic severe + progressive acidosis ( $\leftarrow$ inability to excrete the usual endogenously produced nonvolatile acid) leads to:
> mobilization of calcium + phosphate from bone (osteomalacia)
> growth retardation
> hypercalciuria $\rightarrow 2^{\circ}$ hyperparathyroidism
> loss of phosphate $\rightarrow$ osteomalacia / rickets
(c) nephrocalcinosis + nephrolithiasis $\leftarrow$ combination of hypercalciuria + elevated urine

$\mathrm{pH}+$ marked reduction in urinary citrate
(d) potassium wastage with hyperkaliuria + hypokalemia $\leftarrow$ constant small loss of sodium bicarbonate in urine, reduction of ECF space, $2^{\circ}$ hyperaldosteronism, increase in sodium-potassium exchange in distal tubule
Path: calcium deposits accompanied by chronic interstitial nephritis with cellular infiltration, tubular atrophy, glomerular sclerosis

- muscle weakness, hyporeflexia, paralysis $\leftarrow$ hypokalemia
- bone pain $\leftarrow$ osteomalacia
- polyuria $\leftarrow$ defect in urinary concentrating ability as a result of nephrocalcinosis + potassium deficiency
- low plasma bicarbonate, hypokalemia, loss of sodium
- hyperchloremic acidosis $\leftarrow$ impaired ability to excrete the usual endogenous load of nonvolatile acid
- alkaline urine $=$ urine $\mathrm{pH}>5.0-5.5$
- hypercalciuria $\leftarrow$ continued mobilization of calcium + phosphate from bone $\leftarrow$ metabolic acidosis
- hypocitraturia $\leftarrow$ increased proximal tubular reabsorption of citrate

Dx: acid load test with ammonium chloride (NH4Cl)
$R s:$ administration of a mixture of sodium + potassium bicarbonate
Cx: interstitial nephritis, chronic renal failure (damage from nephrocalcinosis + secondary pyelonephritis), bone lesions, nephrocalcinosis, nephrolithiasis

# Permanent Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis 

$=$ ADULT TYPE OF PRIMARY DISTAL RTA $=$ BUTLER-ALBRIGHT SYNDROME
Genetics: mostly sporadic; may be autosomal dominant
Age: children + adults (usually not diagnosed before age 2); $\mathrm{F}>\mathrm{M}$

- vomiting, constipation, polyuria, dehydration
- failure to thrive, growth retardation, anorexia
- polyuria $\leftarrow$ renal concentrating defect
- potassium loss $\rightarrow$ flaccid paralysis
- bone pain + pathologic fractures in adolescents + adults $\leftarrow$ osteomalacia
- low serum pH , low bicarbonate concentration
- elevation of chloride, urinary pH of 6.0-6.5
$\sqrt{ }$ rickets / osteomalacia
$\sqrt{ }$ moderately retarded bone age
$\sqrt{ }$ medullary nephrocalcinosis / nephrolithiasis (as early as 1 month of age)

> amphotericin B nephropathy, toxicity to lithium, toluene sniffing

syndrome, Marfan syndrome, elliptocytosis

## RENAL VEIN THROMBOSIS

Prevalence: $0.5 \%$ (autopsy)
Cause:
A. Intrinsic
$=$ thrombotic process begins intrarenally within small intrarenal veins $\leftarrow$ acidosis, hemoconcentration, disseminated intravascular coagulation, intrarenal arteriolar constriction reducing venous flow
(a) antenatally: abruptio placentae
(b) neonates (most common): advanced maternal age, glycosuria in infants of diabetic mothers, dehydration from vomiting, diarrhea, enterocolitis, sepsis, polycythemia, birth trauma, left adrenal hemorrhage, prematurity
(c) adults: pyelonephritis, amyloidosis, polyarteritis nodosa, sickle cell anemia, thrombosis of IVC, low flow states (CHF, constrictive pericarditis), diabetic nephropathy, sarcoidosis
> hypercoagulable state:
» nephrotic syndrome: membranous + membrano-proliferative glomerulonephritis (most common), lupoid nephrosis
» SLE
» inherited hypercoagulable state: deficiency of antithrombin III / protein C / protein S
> mechanical process:
» trauma
» neoplasm: renal neoplasia ( $50 \%$ : RCC, TCC, Wilms tumor), left adrenal carcinoma
» abscess
» aneurysm
> left ovarian vein thrombosis
B. Extrinsic umbilical vein catheterization, thrombosis of IVC with extension into renal vein, malpositioned IVC filter, carcinoma of pancreatic tail invading renal vein (in 75\%), pancreatitis, lymphoma, retroperitoneal sarcoma, retroperitoneal fibrosis, metastases to

retroperitoneum (bronchogenic carcinoma)
mnemonic: TEST MAN
Thrombophlebitis
Enterocolitis (dehydration)
Sickle cell disease, Systemic lupus erythematosus
Trauma
Membranous glomerulonephritis
Amyloidosis
Neoplasm
Radiographic appearance varies with:
(1) Rapidity of venous occlusion
(2) Extent of occlusion
(3) Availability of collateral circulation
(4) Site of occlusion in relation to collateral pathways

Pathophysiology: formation of collateral channels develops at 24 hours + peaks at 2 weeks after onset of occlusion
Collaterals: ureteral vein to vesicular veins, pericapsular veins to lumbar veins, azygos vein, portal vein
on left (in addition): gonadal vein, adrenal vein, inferior phrenic veins

## RETROCAVAL URETER

$=$ CIRCUMCAVAL URETER
Etiology: abnormality in embryogenesis of IVC with persistence of right posterior cardinal vein ventral to ureter + failure of right supracardinal system to develop
Prevalence: $0.07 \% ; \mathrm{M} \div \mathrm{F}=3 \div 1$

- symptoms of right ureteral obstruction
$\sqrt{ }$ proximal right ureter swings medially over pedicle of L3-4, passes behind IVC, and emerges to right of aorta $\rightarrow$ returns to its normal position anterior to iliac vessels
$\sqrt{ }$ varying degrees of hydronephrosis + proximal hydrouretero-nephrosis
$C x$ : recurrent urinary tract infections


## RETROPERITONEAL FAT NECROSIS

Cause: fat saponification $\leftarrow$ autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma + peripancreatic fat $\leftarrow$ release of lipolytic enzymes $\leftarrow$ pancreatitis
Pathophysiology:
phospholipases + proteases attack plasma membranes of fat cells $\rightarrow$ release and
hydrolyzation of triglycerides $\rightarrow$ production of free fatty acids $\rightarrow$ combining with serum
calcium $\rightarrow$ precipitate as calcium soap

- hypocalcemia (associated with severe pancreatitis)
$\sqrt{ }$ scattered nodules of fat necrosis throughout retroperitoneum + abdominal cavity:
$\sqrt{ }$ mass effect + delayed contrast enhancement
$D D x$ : peritoneal carcinomatosis


## RETROPERITONEAL FIBROSIS

$=\mathrm{RPF}=$ ORMOND DISEASE $=$ CHRONIC PERIAORTITIS $=$ PERIURETERITIS FIBROSA $=$ GEROTA FASCIITIS $=$ SCLEROSING RETROPERITONEAL GRANULOMA
[John Kelso Ormond (1886-1978), surgeon-in-chief of urology division at Henry Ford Hospital,

Detroit]
$=$ uncommon collagen vascular disease of unknown cause characterized by aggressive confluent fibroproliferative masses in retroperitoneal space leading to progressive encasement of retroperitoneal structures, especially ureters

# Pathogenesis: 

(a) probably autoimmune disease with antibodies to insoluble ceroid + oxidized low-density lipoproteins (by-products of aortic plaque, which has penetrated locally into media) leading to systemic vasculitis
(b) systemic autoimmune / inflammatory disease frequently associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, ankylosing spondylitis, Wegener granulomatosis, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-positive rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, primary biliary cirrhosis
(c) immunoglobulin G4 (IgG4)-related disease (= multifocal fibrosclerosis)

## Classification:

A. Primary / idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis ( $2 / 3$ )

With idiopathic RPF the fibroinflammatory tissue entraps both ureters in most cases causing obstructive uropathy (in $56-100 \%$ ) and subsequent renal failure. Some patients present late with nonfunctioning kidneys.
B. Secondary retroperitoneal fibrosis ( $1 / 3$ )
(1) Drugs ( $12 \%$ ): derivatives of ergot alkaloids (methysergide, ergotamine, lysergic acid diethylamide [LSD]), beta-blocker, phenacetin, hydralazine, methyldopa, amphetamines
(2) Malignancy (in up to $8 \%$ ): desmoplastic response to: lymphoma, Hodgkin disease, carcinoid, retroperitoneal metastases (breast, lung, thyroid, GI tract, GU organs)

- positive tumor markers
$\checkmark$ anterior displacement of aorta + IVC
$\checkmark$ nodularity of retroperitoneal mass
$\checkmark$ hyperintense SI on T2WI
(3) Infection = desmoplastic response to: histoplasmosis, tuberculosis, actinomycosis
(4) Retroperitoneal fluid collection / hematoma / urine extravasation: $\leftarrow$ major trauma, major surgery
(5) Aneurysm of aorta / iliac arteries: desmoplastic response to chronic periaortitis
(6) Connective tissue disease: eg, polyarteritis nodosa
(7) Radiation therapy: fibrosis limited to radiation field

Prevalence: $1.3 \div 100,000$ to $1 \div 200,000$
Peak age: $40-65$ years; $\mathrm{M} \div \mathrm{F}=2 \div 1$ to $3 \div 1$
Path: hard retroperitoneal plaque with ill-defined margins enveloping abdominal aorta, iliac vessels, IVC, ureters
Histo:
(a) early: immature fibrotic process with capillary proliferation + diffuse perivascular infiltrate of T and B lymphocytes, plasma cells + fibroblasts in loose matrix of collagen fibers
(b) later: mature plaque composed of relatively acellular and avascular hyalinized collagen + scattered calcifications

May be associated with: asbestos exposure

- weight loss, nausea, malaise, anorexia, low-grade fever
- dull pain in costovertebral angle, back, abdomen ( $90 \%$ )
- obstructive uropathy $\rightarrow$ oliguria $\rightarrow$ anuria $\rightarrow$ renal insufficiency ( $50-60 \%$ )
- renal vessel involvement ( $2-35 \%$ ) $\rightarrow$ hypertension $\rightarrow$ renal insufficiency
- lymphatic + venous obstruction $\rightarrow$ lower extremity edema, deep vein thrombosis (6\%), hydrocele ( $10 \%$ ), scrotal swelling, varicocele
- compression of arteries $\rightarrow$ bowel ischemia, claudication (occasionally)
- high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), anemia
- high levels of C-reactive protein ( $80-100 \%$ )
- tests for antinuclear antibodies may be positive

Location: plaque typically begins around aortic bifurcation (L4-5) extending cephalad to renal hilum / surrounding kidney, duodenum, pancreas and spleen; rarely extends below pelvic rim, but may extend caudad to bladder + rectosigmoid

Retroperitoneal fibrosis most commonly surrounds the infrarenal abdominal aorta and proximal common iliac arteries.
$\sqrt{ }$ tethering of aorta / IVC to vertebrae without anterior displacement
$\checkmark$ usually mild uni- / bilateral pyelocaliectasis $\rightarrow$ hydronephrosis $\rightarrow$ renal failure ( $56-100 \%$ )
$\diamond$ Diagnostic clue: incongruity between severe degree of renal failure + mild degree of hydronephrosis!
IVP / retrograde pyelography:
$\checkmark$ Classic TRIAD:
(1) Ureterectasis above L4-5 $\leftarrow$ interference with peristalsis
(2) Medial deviation of ureters in middle third, typically bilateral = maiden waist deformity
(3) Gradual tapering of ureters at lower lumbar spine / upper sacral region $\leftarrow$ extrinsic compression
$D D x$ : primary ureteral tumor, periureteral lymph nodes, inflammatory ureteral stricture US (poor sensitivity):
$\checkmark$ hypo- / isoechoic well-demarcated irregularly contoured homogeneous mass with smooth margins anterior to lower lumbar spine / sacral promontory
$\checkmark$ varying degrees of uni- / bilateral hydronephrosis
$\checkmark$ NO flow on Doppler imaging
CT:
$\checkmark$ well-delimited irregular periaortic rindlike layer of soft tissue isoattenuating to muscle
$\checkmark$ contrast enhancement (during active inflammation of immature plaque)
$\checkmark$ localized reactive infracentimetric lymphadenopathy ( $25 \%$ )
$\checkmark$ NO aortic displacement (!)
CT / MR allow comprehensive evaluation of morphology, location and extent of RPF + involvement of adjacent organs and vascular structures. They may detect diseases often associated with idiopathic RPF (eg, autoimmune pancreatitis) or an underlying cause of secondary RPF (eg, malignancy).
MR:
$\diamond$ In impaired renal function use HASTE + RARE urography

$\sqrt{ }$ low to medium homogeneous signal intensity on T1WI
$\sqrt{ }$ T2WI:
(a) acute phase $\rightarrow$ inflammatory edema
$\sqrt{ }$ heterogeneous high SI on T2WI (DDx: malignancy)
$\sqrt{ }$ early soft-tissue enhancement mirrors degree of inflammatory activity
(b) chronic phase $\rightarrow$ dense fibrotic plaque
$\sqrt{ }$ low SI on T2WI
$\sqrt{ }$ little / NO enhancement during venous phase
$\sqrt{ }$ delayed enhancement
NUC:
$\sqrt{ } 67 \mathrm{Ga}$-citrate uptake during active inflammation
$\sqrt{ }$ little / NO gallium uptake in chronic fibrotic stage
PET:
$\sqrt{ }$ increased uptake of FDG paralleling degree of activity
$\sqrt{ }$ may detect remote disease (multifocal fibrosclerosis, infectious / neoplastic disease, other autoimmune process)
${ }^{18} \mathrm{~F}$-FDG PET is the most sensitive modality for
(a) assessing metabolic activity of residual masses,
(b) demonstrating relapse.
$D x$ : open surgical / laparoscopic biopsy preferred for differentiation of benign from malignant disease

Histologic evaluation of biopsy tissue is mandatory to establish a definitive diagnosis if there are (a) findings suggestive of underlying malignancy or infection; (b) atypical location of the retroperitoneal mass (eg, pelvic, peripancreatic, perirenal); (c) progression of the mass or absence of response to immunosuppressive therapy.
Prognosis: chronic relapsing course
The most important challenge is to differentiate benign from malignant RPF because benign forms of RPF have a good outcome, whereas RPF secondary to malignancy has a poor prognosis.
$D D x$ : (1) Perianeurysmal fibrosis (dilated encased aorta)
(2) Malignant retroperitoneal fibrosis / sarcoma (mass with irregular lobular / nodular margins, more cephalad location, anterior displacement of aorta, edema, Doppler flow, contrast enhancement)
(3) Retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, lymphoma (anterior elevation of aorta / IVC off vertebral body)
(4) Primary amyloidosis
(5) Subacute retroperitoneal hematoma
$R x$ : (1) Withdrawal of possible causative agent
(2) Interventional relief of urinary obstruction
(3) Corticosteroids / immunotherapeutic drugs
(4) Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, tamoxifen
(5) Ureterolysis for refractory cases

# RETROPERITONEAL LEIOMYOSARCOMA 

Frequency: $2^{\text {nd }}$ most common ( $28 \%$ ) primary retroperitoneal malignancy (after liposarcoma)
Path: necrosis + cystic degeneration + hemorrhage in large tumor; calcifications uncommon Age: $5^{\text {th }}-6^{\text {th }}$ decade; $\mathrm{M} \circ \mathrm{F}=1 \circ 6$

- abdominal mass, pain, weight loss, nausea, vomiting
- abdominal distension, change in defecation habits, leg edema, back / radicular pain, frequency of urination
- hemoperitoneum, GI bleeding, dystocia, paraplegia

Site:
(a) retroperitoneal space without attachment to organs
(b) wall of inferior vena cava (in $6 \%$ of leiomyosarcomas)

Size: average diameter $>10 \mathrm{~cm}$
Metastases:
frequently hematogenous, less commonly lymphatic dissemination

## SCHISTOSOMIASIS

$=$ BILHARZIASIS $=$ SNAIL FEVER
[schisto, Greek = split; soma, Greek = body]
[Theodor Maximilian Bilharz (1825-1862), German physician and parasitologist, chair of descriptive anatomy at Kasr el Aïn, Cairo]
$\diamond$ One of the most protean diseases in humans ( $>200$ million people infected in Africa, Asia, and the Americas)!
$\diamond 2^{\text {nd }}$ most common cause of mortality among parasitic infections after malaria $\rightarrow 500,000$ deaths annually!
$\diamond$ The most prevalent waterborne disease!
Organism: S. haematobium (GU tract) $>95 \%$;
S. mansoni, S. japonicum (GI tract) $<5 \%$

Contact: exposure of skin to water contaminated with cercariae excreted by snails as a result of unsanitary disposal of human and animal wastes combined with repeated daily contact with contaminated freshwater (eg, fishing, farming, swimming, bathing, recreation)

- dermatitis $=$ swimmer's itch (common manifestation) $\leftarrow$ juvenile worms enter circulatory system
- "Katayama fever" = fever, chills, sweating, cough (occasional) $\leftarrow$ adult female worms develop in GU and GI tracts
$R x:$ praziquantel (destroys adult worms + incites eggs to hatch), albendazole


## Schistosoma Hematobium

Prevalence: 8\% of world's population; 25\% in Africa
Endemic to: South Africa, Egypt, Nigeria, Tanzania, Zimbabwe; South America; Carribean; Middle East; Asia; Puerto Rico
Life cycle:
female parasite resides within venules of urinary bladder $\rightarrow$ eggs erode bladder mucosa $\rightarrow$ excreted with urine and feces $\rightarrow$ hatch in fresh water into larval miracidia
larvae invade aquatic / amphibious fresh-water snails (= intermediate host) of genus
Bulinus $\rightarrow$ miracidia develop into adult sporocytes $\rightarrow$ in 4-6 weeks thousands of fork-
tailed free swimming $1-\mathrm{mm}$ long cercariae are released $\rightarrow$ pass into surrounding body of water
$\rightarrow$ death within 72 hours OR

penetration of human skin (usually foot) where they lose their tail $\rightarrow$ pass into lymphatics + thoracic duct $\rightarrow$ travel to RT heart + lungs $\rightarrow$ LT heart + mesenteric capillaries $\rightarrow$ reach portal vein where they mature into adult worms + copulate (in 21 days after penetration) $\rightarrow$ return into pelvic venous plexus where they may live for many years
Histo: eggs incite granulomatous response + fibrosis $\rightarrow$ polypoid lesions (acute phase) and ultimately SCC (chronic phase); large number of eggs calcify in bladder wall without viable eggs in urine
Definite $D x$ : eggs found at urine microscopy

- frequency, urgency, dysuria
- terminal microscopic hematuria, hemospermia
- albuminuria in the nephrotic range (most common)
- suprapubic pain; dull flank pain (from hydronephrosis)
- hypertrophic, ulcerative, fistulous, wart-like lesions of vulva + perineum (can be mistaken for condylomata lata)
- index of infectious severity = urine egg count

Location: lower ureters + bladder
@ Urinary bladder
Pathogenesis:
chronic irritation of mucosa $\rightarrow$ proliferation of urothelium into buds (von Brunn nests)
$\rightarrow$ growth into lamina propria $\rightarrow$
(a) cystic deposits = cystitis cystica
(b) intestinal mucin-secreting glands (goblet cells) = cystitis glandularis
$\checkmark$ polypoid filling defects + mucosal irregularities in urinary bladder (pseudotubercles, papillomas) during acute phase $\leftarrow$ cystitis cystica
$\checkmark$ bladder wall calcifications (in 4-56\%): curvilinear / coarse / floccular, beginning at base parallel to upper aspect of pubic bone, involving all wall layers:
$\checkmark$ calcified bladder resembling a fetal head (PATHOGNOMONIC)
$\diamond$ Calcifications present with an abundance of calcified dead ova in submucosa in chronic stage
$\checkmark$ thick-walled fibrotic "flat-topped" bladder with high insertion of ureters
$\checkmark$ reduced bladder capacity (fibrotic stage) $\rightarrow$ significant postvoid residual
$\checkmark$ vesical calculi (in 39\%), distal ureteral calcification (in 34\%), honeycombed calcification of seminal vesicles
Cx: Squamous cell carcinoma of bladder (SCC)
Age: 30-50 years (exposed early in childhood with 20-30-year latency period)
Location: posterior bladder wall, rarely trigone
$\checkmark$ nodular / fungating filling defect ( $80 \%$ )
$\checkmark$ diffuse / focal region of wall thickening
$\checkmark$ multiple tumors $(25 \%)$
$\checkmark$ discontinuous calcifications
@ Ureter (in up to $65 \%$ )
$\checkmark$ persistent filling defect of distal ureteral segment with ureterectasis $\leftarrow$ peristaltic disorganization $\leftarrow$ focal egg deposition
$\checkmark$ beaded appearance of ureter:

$\sqrt{ }$ air bubble-like filling defect $=$ ureteritis cystica
$\checkmark$ multiple inflammatory pseudopolyps in ureter $\leftarrow$ granulomas (= bilharziomas)
$\checkmark$ ureteral strictures in distal third (in $8 \%, \mathrm{~L}>\mathrm{R}$ ), most commonly in intravesical portion with cobra-head configuration $=$ pseudoureterocele; Makar stricture $=$ focal stricture at L3
$\checkmark$ linear wall calcifications $=$ ureteritis calcinosa (PATHOGNOMONIC)
$\checkmark$ vesicoureteral reflux (in up to $30 \%$ )
$\checkmark$ striation of renal pelvis + proximal ureter in $21 \%$ (DDx: normal in $3 \%$, other urinary tract infection, vesicoureteric reflux
$C x$ : hydroureteronephrosis $\leftarrow$ cessation of peristalsis
@ Urethra
$\checkmark$ polyps in fossa navicularis of urethra
$\checkmark$ urethral stricture with perineal and scrotal fistulas
@ Scrotum

# Schistosoma Mansoni \& Japonicum 

Organism:

## A. Schistosoma mansoni

Endemic to: Africa, Saudi Arabia, Madagascar, Brazil, Surinam, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, Middle East
Path: eggs deposited along large portal veins of liver hilum

## B. Schistosoma japonicum

Endemic to: east Asia, China, Philippines
Path: eggs deposited in peripheral small portal veins
Intermediate host: snail
Life cycle:
(a) within snail : miracidia mature into cercariae $\rightarrow$ released into water + swim $\rightarrow$ penetrate skin / intestinal wall of human host
(b) within human: in mesenteric veins
> migration via blood + lymph vessels into lung $\rightarrow$ afterward liver $\rightarrow$ eggs released into portal circulation
> adult worm inhabits inferior mesenteric + portal veins
> eggs excreted in human feces $\rightarrow$ reach water $\rightarrow$ hatching of miracidia $\rightarrow$ infection of snails
Path: (a) intestinal schistosomiasis:
> exudative granulomatous response (proctocolitis) $\rightarrow$ formation of inflammatory polyps, fibrosis, wall thickening, colonic stenosis
(b) hepatosplenic schistosomiasis:
> liver granulomas $\rightarrow$ periportal (Symmers) fibrosis $\rightarrow$ fibrosis-induced presinusoidal portal hypertension
> chronic endothelial inflammation $\rightarrow$ venous thrombosis

$D x$ : eggs identified in stool specimen / rectal biopsy
Cx: (1) Splenomegaly with siderotic nodules
(2) Portal vein thrombosis with collateral circulation $\rightarrow$ gastrointestinal hemorrhage
(3) Portal cholangiopathy $\rightarrow$ cavernous transformation of portal vein $\rightarrow$ biliary obstruction with jaundice
(4) Portal hypertension $\rightarrow$ eggs shunted from portal system into pulmonary vasculature
@ GI tract
$\checkmark$ esophageal varices $\leftarrow$ portal hypertension
$\checkmark$ polypoid calcifying bowel lesions $\leftarrow$ eggs of S. mansoni trapped in bowel wall + inciting granulomatous reaction)
$D D x$ : isolated intestinal schistosomiasis may be indistinguishable from other forms of proctocolitis.
@ Liver
$\checkmark$ severe splenomegaly with siderotic nodules
$\checkmark$ atrophy of right hepatic lobe + widening of fissures
$\checkmark$ portal hypertension $\leftarrow$ fibrosing granulomatous reaction within presinusoidal portal veins $\leftarrow$ ova migrating into portal venous system
$\checkmark$ periportal hyperechogenicity
$\checkmark$ gallbladder wall thickening
MR:
$\checkmark$ high-signal-intensity bands along portal tracts on T2WI $\leftarrow$ periportal fibrosis
$\checkmark$ low signal intensity bands on T1WI enhance during venous phase
Advanced-stage hepatosplenic schistosomiasis causes marked morphologic changes in the liver with periportal fibrosis, signs of portal hypertension and severe splenomegaly with siderotic nodules.
@ Lung
> early form (3-8 weeks after parasitic penetration)

- shortness of breath, wheezing, dry cough
- eosinophilia $\leftarrow$ immunologic type 3 reaction
- Katayama fever = pulmonary symptoms coincide with febrile illness $\leftarrow$ immunologic reaction to parasite eggs
Associated with: hepatosplenomegaly, hepatitis, urticaria, arthralgia
$\checkmark$ diffuse small nodular granulomatous lung lesions with ill-defined borders
$\checkmark$ reticulonodular pattern (less common)
$\checkmark$ bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities / hyperattenuation
> late form = granulomatous type 4 reaction to eggs deposited in pulmonary vasculature $\rightarrow$ intimal fibrosis, pulmonary hypertension, cor pulmonale
- dyspnea, chest pain, fatigue, palpitations, cough
- right-sided heart failure (late)
$\checkmark$ cardiomegaly
$\checkmark$ enlargement of RV + pulmonary artery + azygos vein (from portal hypertension)

## SPERMATIC CORD TORSION

$=$ TESTICULAR TORSION = TWISTING OF SPERMATIC CORD
$\diamond$ Most common scrotal disorder in children, $20 \%$ of acute scrotal pathology

Etiology:
(1) Intravaginal torsion (= torsion distal to attachment of tunica vaginalis) = "bell and clapper" deformity = high insertion of tunica vaginalis on spermatic cord in $12 \%$ of males
Site: in 5\% bilateral $\leftarrow$ anomalous suspension of contralateral testis found in $80 \%$ Age: any, predominantly adolescence
(2) Extravaginal torsion $(10 \%)=$ torsion proximal to attach-ment of tunica vaginalis involving testis + tunica vaginalis $\leftarrow$ loose attachment of testicular tunics to scrotum Age: in utero (mostly) + perinatal period; may be bilateral

(3) Abnormally loose mesorchium between testis + epididymis

Peak age: newborn period + puberty (13-16 years); $<20[>21]\{>30\}$ years in $74-85 \%$
$[26 \%]\{9 \%\}$

## Acute Testicular Torsion

$=$ symptoms present for $<24$ hours

- $70 \%$ of patients present within first 6 hours from onset of pain:
- sudden severe pain in $100 \%$ (frequently at night)
- negative urine analysis ( $98 \%$ ), nausea + vomiting ( $50 \%$ )
- history of similar episode in same / contralateral testis ( $42 \%$ ); history of trauma / extreme exertion $(13 \%)$
- scrotal swelling + tenderness ( $42 \%$ )
- leukocytosis ( $32 \%$ ), low-grade fever ( $20 \%$ )
- Brunzel sign = elevated horizontal lie of testis
- Ger sign = skin pitting at scrotal base

# SURGICALEMERGENCY! 

Testicular viability related to:
(a) degree of torsion ( $720^{\circ}$ necessary for complete ischemia)

Degree of torsion and blood flow:

- testis usually turns medially up to $1,080^{\circ}$
$\sqrt{ }$ diminished blood flow in $<180^{\circ}$-torsion at 1 hour
$\sqrt{ }$ absent blood flow in any degree of torsion $>4$ hours
(b) length of ischemia

Salvage rate versus time from onset of pain to surgery
$97-100 \%<6 \mathrm{hrs} \quad 57 \% 6-12 \mathrm{hrs}$
$35 \% 12-24 \mathrm{hrs} \quad 0-9 \%>24 \mathrm{hrs}$
$\diamond$ Irreversible ischemic damage begins at 3-6 hours after onset of torsion!
(c) intermittent torsion
$\diamond$ Spontaneous detorsion in $7 \%$
$\checkmark$ hyperemia after spontaneous detorsion
US ( $80-90 \%$ sensitivity):
$\checkmark$ testicular echogenicity:
$\checkmark$ normal grey-scale appearance (within 1-3-6 hours)
$\checkmark$ diffusely hypoechoic echotexture ( $>6$ hours)
$\checkmark$ heterogeneous echotexture $\leftarrow$ ischemic necrosis
$\checkmark$ testicular size:
$\checkmark$ normal size $=80 \%$ salvage rate
$\checkmark$ testicular + epididymal enlargement with decreased echogenicity (within 8-24 hours)
$\diamond$ Torsion has no / minimal epididymal flow (DDx: acute epididymitis has increased flow)
$\checkmark$ extratesticular findings:
$\checkmark$ scrotal skin thickening
$\checkmark$ hydrocele (occasionally)
$\checkmark$ "torsion knot" sign = twisted enlarged spermatic cord with spiraling vessels at external inguinal orifice
$\checkmark$ intrascrotal portion of cord round / ovoid / curled with epididymal head wrapped around it
$\checkmark$ inverted orientation of testis + epididymis + cord (in 6\%)
Pitfall: dilated cord mistaken for abnormal epididymis
Color duplex ( $86 \%$ sensitive, $100 \%$ specific, $97 \%$ accurate):
N.B.: contralateral testis $=$ internal normal control (!)
$\checkmark$ loss of spermatic cord Doppler signal ( $44 \%$ sensitive, $67 \%$ specific)
$\checkmark$ absence of testicular + epididymal flow (DDx: global testicular infarction)
$\checkmark$ diminished flow (veins affected before arteries) $\leftarrow$ incomplete $\left(<360^{\circ}\right) /$ intermittent torsion:
$\checkmark$ some arterial flow persists (in $20 \%$ of torsions)
$\checkmark$ high-resistance waveform $=$ decreased / reversed arterial flow in diastole
False-negative: torsion-detorsion sequence, incomplete torsion $<360$ degrees
False-positive: in small boys $<4$ years of age ( $=$ limitation of color Doppler sensitivity)

Dose: $5-15 \mathrm{mCi}{ }^{99 \mathrm{~m}} \mathrm{Tc}$-pertechnetate

# TESTICULAR CANCER 

$\diamond$ Most common neoplasm in males between ages 15 and 35 years; $0.5 \%$ of all cancers in males; $4-6 \%$ of all male genitourinary tumors; $1 \%$ of all childhood malignancies; $4^{\text {th }}$ most common cause of death from malignancy between ages $15-34$ years ( $12 \%$ )
Incidence annually: $5.7 \div 100,000$ in 2016 (4.1 100,000 in 1975); 1 263 males; 8,720 new cases in USA (2016)
Peak age: 25-35 years; 71-90 years; infants $<3$ years: yolk sac tumor + teratoma; White $\div$ Black $=4.5 \div 1$
Risk factors:
(1) Prior testicular cancer ( $20 \times$ risk $=2-5 \%$ )
(2) Maldescension = cryptorchidism (10 x risk)
$5 \%$ for abdominal site, $1.25 \%$ for inguinal site
Rx: orchiopexy
(3) Family history of testicular cancer ( 6 x risk for $1^{\text {st }}$-degree relative $=2 \%$ )
more prevalent in Caucasian race, Jewish religion
(4) Infertility ( $0.4-1.1 \%$ prevalence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia)
(5) Intersex syndrome: gonadal dysgenesis, true hermaphroditism, pseudohermaphroditism

- painless enlarging testis / mass ( $90 \%$ ), however:
- acute scrotal pain ( $10 \%$, from intratumoral hemorrhage)
- "heaviness / fullness" in lower abdomen / scrotum
- gynecomastia, virilization

Location: mostly unilateral; contralateral tumor develops eventually in $8 \%$
Metastases: at presentation in $4-14 \%$
(a) lymphatic dissemination
testicular lymphatic drainage follows gonadal veins to
> interaortocaval chain at L2 (for right testicular tumor)
> left paraaortic nodes between renal vein, aorta, ureter and inferior mesenteric artery
along thoracic duct
> left supraclavicular nodes
> lungs
(b) hematogenous dissemination (usually late) to lung > liver, brain, bone
$\diamond$ Choriocarcinoma has a proclivity for early hematogenous spread (especially to brain)!
(c) direct extension through tunica albuginea to skin (rare and late) / epididymis $\rightarrow$ spread to inguinal + iliac nodes
Histo: may be different from that of primary tumor indicating totipotential nature of germ cells
Tumor markers (elevated in $80 \%$ at time of diagnosis):
$\alpha$ yolk sac tumors, mixed germ cell tumors with yolk sac elements
